explanation: The target function calls sysctlbyname and sysctl, which are system library functions used for querying system information. To analyze the function for MISRA C rule violations regarding memcmp usage on strings, these functions and their usage must be understood to confirm if any string comparisons occur internally that might violate the rule. The macros CTL_HW and HW_NCPU are used as indices in sysctl calls and are needed to understand the context of the sysctl usage. The preprocessor conditionals (#ifndef __linux__, #ifdef HAVE_SYSCTLBYNAME, #if defined(HAVE_SYSCTL) && defined(HAS_DECL_CTL_HW) && defined(HAS_DECL_HW_NCPU)) control whether parts of the code compile, so they must be known to determine which code paths are active. There is no direct use of memcmp or string comparison in the target function itself, so checking these symbols will assist in verifying compliance with the MISRA rule.
